Category: Fertilizers

A fertilizer or fertiliser is any material of natural or synthetic origin that is applied to soil or to plant tissues to supply plant nutrients. Fertilizers may be distinct from liming materials or other non-nutrient soil amendments. Many sources of fertilizer exist, both natural and industrially produced.

Poorna - 19

In botany, a seed is a plant embryo and food reserve enclosed in a protective outer covering called a seed coat. More generally, the term seed means anything that can be sown, which may include seed and husk or tuber. Seeds are the product of the ripened ovule, after the embryo sac is fertilized by sperm from pollen, forming a zygote

Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi

Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi (PMKISAN, translation: Prime Minister\'s Farmer\'s Tribute Fund) is an initiative by the government of India that give farmers up to ₹6,000 (US$75) per year as minimum income support. The initiative was announced by Piyush Goyal during the 2019 Interim Union Budget of India on 1 February 2019.
Organic Farming Incentive Scheme

This scheme promotes cluster-based organic farming with Participatory Guarantee System (PGS) certification. Farmers receive assistance of ₹25,000 per hectare for three years for organic inputs, including organic manure and bio-fertilizers.
Chief Minister Solar Agriculture Pump Scheme 2023

A new scheme named ‘Magel tyala Solar Krishipump’ will be launched for the farmers, under which 8.50 lakh solar agricultural pumps will be installed,” Pawar announced, adding 37,000 anganwadis will be provided with solar sets.
Agricultural Mortgage Loan Scheme

In this scheme, as a farmer, you can keep your produce in the warehouse of the Agricultural Produce Market Committee and get 75% of the price of that product as a loan. When the prices of products go up in the market, you can sell your product in the market and repay the loan. This plan is a boon in terms of getting a better price for your product.
Subsidy Scheme For Export Of Agricultural Produce By Sea

In this scheme, anyone who exports a specified agricultural product from a cooperative society, farmer producer group/company, institution, exporter or farmer will be charged with Rs. 50,000/- per container (20 feet/40 feet) will be eligible for the subsidy. The maximum annual subsidy per beneficiary will be Rs 1 lakh.
Category: Herbicides
It is a pre emergence herbicide which prevents the emergence of most of the grassy and broad leaf weeds. It is also used as early post emergence application at 2-3 leaf.

Organic Farming

An ancient farming technique that uses natural organic wastes and green manure, and avoids artificial fertilizers. It protects soil fertility through soil microorganisms and nitrogen self-sufficiency.
A soil-less farming technique that can increase crop yields while reducing water usage and chemical inputs.
Hydroponics
Precision farming
An emerging field in India that can help improve the productivity, profitability, and sustainability of farming practices.
Aeroponics system

A soil-less farming technique that involves growing plants in a misty environment without soil. This technique is becoming popular in India because it can help with water conservation, higher crop yields, and growing crops in limited spaces.
Aquaponics
A food production system that can provide a livelihood for marginal farmers and unemployed youths.
Crop rotation
A method of farming that involves cultivating different crops in a fixed rotation pattern to maintain soil fertility.
Plantation farming is a form of agriculture where an area of ground is cleared of vegetation and cultivated for a few years and then abandoned for a new area.
User Name
Canal
Cancel

Organic farming is a method of crop and livestock production that involves much more than simply avoiding synthetic pesticides and fertilizers. It focuses on holistic, sustainable practices that promote soil health, biodiversity, and environmental conservation.
Soil Management

Compost: Utilize organic materials such as kitchen waste, crop residues, and animal manure to create compost. Compost enriches the soil with nutrients, improves soil structure, and enhances microbial activity.
Crop Rotation: Rotate crops seasonally to prevent soil depletion and nutrient imbalance. Different crops have different nutrient requirements, and rotating them helps maintain soil fertility.
Cover Crops: Plant cover crops like legumes or grasses during fallow periods to protect soil from erosion, suppress weeds, and fix nitrogen in the soil.
Weed Management
Mechanical Control: Use hand tools, mechanical weeders, or mulching to control weeds without relying on synthetic herbicides.
Crop Diversity: Planting diverse crops helps suppress weed growth by shading the soil and reducing weed establishment.
Pest and Disease Management
Biological Control: Introduce natural predators, parasites, or pathogens to control pest populations. For example, ladybugs for aphids or nematodes for soil pests
Crop Diversity: Diverse cropping systems disrupt pest life cycles and reduce the likelihood of pest outbreaks
Trap Crops: Plant specific crops that attract pests away from primary crops, acting as sacrificial plants
Fertilization
Organic Fertilizers: Use natural sources of nutrients such as compost, manure, bone meal, and seaweed extracts.
Crop Rotation: Rotate nitrogen-fixing legumes with other crops to replenish soil nitrogen levels naturally.
Green Manure: Grow crops specifically to be plowed back into the soil to improve soil fertility and organic matter content.
Water Management
Drip Irrigation: Use drip irrigation systems to deliver water directly to plant roots, minimizing water wastage and reducing the risk of disease.
Mulching: Apply organic mulch (e.g., straw, leaves, or grass clippings) around plants to conserve soil moisture, suppress weeds, and maintain soil temperature.
Rainwater Harvesting: Collect rainwater in barrels or cisterns for irrigation during dry periods, reducing dependence on municipal water sources.
plantation farming
Hydroponics is a method of growing plants without soil, using a nutrient-rich water solution to deliver essential minerals directly to the plant roots.
Basic Principle

In hydroponic systems, plants are grown in an inert growing medium such as perlite, vermiculite, or coconut coir, which provides support to the plant roots while allowing them to access the nutrient solution.
Types of Hydroponic Systems
Deep Water Culture (DWC): Plants are suspended above a reservoir of nutrient solution, with their roots submerged in the water.
Nutrient Film Technique (NFT): A shallow stream of nutrient solution continuously flows over the roots of the plants, providing a constant supply of nutrients
Ebb and Flow (Flood and Drain): Plants are periodically flooded with nutrient solution and then drained, allowing the roots access to oxygen between cycles.
Drip System: Nutrient solution is dripped onto the base of each plant using a drip emitter, providing precise control over nutrient delivery.
Nutrient Solution

The nutrient solution used in hydroponics contains a carefully balanced mix of essential minerals, including nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, calcium, magnesium, and trace elements. The solution is pH-balanced to ensure optimal nutrient uptake by the plants.
Advantages of Hydroponics
Efficient use of water and nutrients
Faster growth rates and higher yields
Year-round cultivation regardless of climate
Reduced reliance on pesticides and herbicides
Space-saving design, suitable for urban agriculture
Oxygenation
Proper oxygenation of the nutrient solution is essential for healthy root development and preventing root rot. Air stones or pumps are used to oxygenate the solution in DWC and other systems.

Precision farming is an approach to crop management that uses technology such as GPS, sensors, drones, and data analytics to monitor and manage crop variability in real-time, allowing farmers to make informed decisions and apply inputs precisely where and when they are needed.
Global Positioning System (GPS)
GPS technology enables precise mapping and monitoring of field boundaries, soil characteristics, and crop health.
GPS data is used to create detailed field maps, allowing farmers to identify variability in soil types, nutrient levels, and moisture content.
Remote Sensing

Remote sensing technologies, such as satellite imagery and drones, provide high-resolution images of fields, allowing farmers to monitor crop health, detect pest infestations, and assess environmental conditions.
Remote sensing data is used to generate vegetation indices (e.g., NDVI) that indicate plant vigor and stress levels.
Variable Rate Technology (VRT)
VRT enables the precise application of inputs such as fertilizers, pesticides, and water based on spatial variability within the field.
VRT systems use GPS-guided equipment to adjust application rates in real-time, optimizing resource use and minimizing waste
Soil and Crop Monitoring
Soil sensors and probes are used to measure soil moisture, temperature, pH, and nutrient levels at multiple locations within the field.
Crop sensors and cameras monitor plant health parameters such as chlorophyll content, canopy temperature, and leaf area index.
Data Analytics and Decision Support Systems
Data analytics tools analyze information collected from various sources, including GPS, remote sensing, and sensor networks, to generate actionable insights and recommendations
Decision support systems provide farmers with personalized recommendations for crop management practices, input application, and irrigation scheduling.
Benefits of Precision Farming
Increased crop yields and quality
Enhanced resource efficiency (water, fertilizers, pesticides)
Reduced environmental impact (e.g., reduced runoff, soil erosion)
Improved farm profitability and sustainability
Better resilience to climate variability and extreme weather events
Aeroponics is a soilless farming technique where plants are grown suspended in air, and their roots are continuously misted with a nutrient-rich solution.
Root Environmen

In aeroponics, plant roots are exposed to oxygen-rich air, promoting rapid and healthy growth. The absence of soil allows roots to access oxygen more efficiently, enhancing nutrient uptake and minimizing the risk of root diseases.
Nutrient Delivery

Nutrient solution is delivered directly to plant roots through misting nozzles or sprayers. The solution is composed of water mixed with essential nutrients required for plant growth, including nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and micronutrients.
Misting System

Aeroponic systems utilize misting systems to deliver the nutrient solution. These systems typically consist of high-pressure pumps, distribution lines, and misting nozzles. The misting process ensures uniform coverage of plant roots and optimal nutrient absorption.
Plant Support Structure
Plants in aeroponic systems are supported using structures such as vertical towers, trays, or racks. These structures hold the plants in place while allowing their roots to hang freely in the air.
Optimized Growing Environment

Aeroponic systems are often housed in controlled environments such as greenhouses or indoor grow rooms. Temperature, humidity, and light levels are carefully regulated to create an ideal growing environment for plants.
Lighting

Artificial lighting, such as LED grow lights, is used to provide plants with the necessary light for photosynthesis. The lighting schedule can be customized based on the specific requirements of the plant species being grown.
Water Conservation:
Aeroponic systems are highly water-efficient compared to traditional soil-based farming methods. The closed-loop system recirculates water, minimizing waste and reducing overall water consumption.
Advantages
Faster growth rates and higher yields compared to traditional farming methods.
Reduced water consumption and nutrient usage
Minimized risk of soil-borne diseases and pests.
Year-round cultivation in controlled environments.
Suitable for urban agriculture and locations with limited arable land.

Aquaponics is a sustainable farming method that combines aquaculture (fish farming) with hydroponics (soilless plant cultivation). It creates a symbiotic ecosystem where fish waste provides nutrients for plants, and plants help purify the water for the fish
Fish Tanks

Aquaponics systems begin with fish tanks, where aquatic species such as tilapia, trout, or catfish are raised. The fish produce waste (ammonia) as a byproduct of their metabolism, which accumulates in the water.
Grow Beds

The nutrient-rich water from the fish tanks is then circulated to grow beds, which contain plants. These beds can be filled with gravel, clay pellets, or other inert media that support the plants. The plant roots absorb the nutrients from the water, filtering out the waste and purifying it.
Beneficial Bacteria:

In aquaponics, beneficial bacteria play a crucial role in the nitrogen cycle. Nitrosomonas bacteria convert ammonia into nitrites, and Nitrobacter bacteria further break down nitrites into nitrates, which are essential nutrients for plants. This process, known as nitrification, helps maintain water quality for both fish and plants.
Water Circulation

The water is continuously circulated between the fish tanks and grow beds through a pump system. As it flows through the grow beds, plants absorb nutrients, and the filtered water returns to the fish tanks, providing a clean environment for the fish.
Temperature Control

Aquaponics systems require stable water temperatures to support fish and plant growth. Temperature control measures such as heaters, chillers, or natural shading help maintain optimal conditions throughout the year, especially in regions with extreme climates.
Fish and Plant Selection

The choice of fish and plants depends on various factors such as climate, water temperature, and market demand. Warm-water fish like tilapia are commonly used in tropical climates, while cold-water species like trout are suitable for cooler regions. Leafy greens, herbs, tomatoes, and cucumbers are popular choices for aquaponic cultivation.
Sustainability

Aquaponics is an eco-friendly farming method that conserves water and resources compared to traditional agriculture. It requires significantly less water than soil-based farming and eliminates the need for chemical fertilizers, pesticides, and herbicides.
Reduced environmental impact
Integration of fish and plant production in a single system
Scalability for small-scale and commercial operations

While the benefits of crop rotation may not be immediately apparent, they accumulate over time. By investing in soil health and ecosystem resilience through crop rotation, farmers can sustainably maintain and enhance agricultural productivity for future generations
Long-Term Benefits

Crop rotation patterns can vary depending on the specific objectives and constraints of the farm. Common rotation schemes include simple rotations (e.g., corn-soybean-wheat), complex rotations (e.g., four-year or five-year rotations with multiple crops), and cover crop rotations (e.g., planting cover crops between cash crops).
Rotation Patterns

Effective crop rotation requires careful planning and management. Farmers need to consider factors such as crop compatibility, nutrient cycling, pest and disease history, and market demand when designing rotation sequences.
Planning and Management

Crop rotation can lead to higher yields and better crop quality over time. By optimizing soil health, managing pests and diseases, and reducing weed pressure, farmers can achieve more robust and sustainable
mproved Yields and Quality

Certain crops, especially monocultures, can deplete specific nutrients from the soil and increase susceptibility to pests and diseases. Crop rotation breaks this cycle by introducing different crops with different nutrient
Break Crop Cycle

: Crop rotation can help control weeds by disrupting their growth cycles. Some crops, like certain cover crops, have allelopathic properties that inhibit weed germination and growth. Additionally, rotating crops with different canopy structures and growth habits can shade out weeds and reduce competition.
Weed Suppression

Different crops have varying nutrient requirements and root structures. By rotating crops, farmers can prevent nutrient depletion and soil erosion, maintain soil structure, and enhance soil fertility. Leguminous crops, such as peas and beans, fix nitrogen in the soil, benefiting subsequent crops.
Soil Health Improvement

Crop rotation involves alternating the types of crops grown in a particular field over time. For example, a farmer might rotate between legumes (e.g., beans, peas), cereals (e.g., wheat, corn), and root crops (e.g., potatoes, carrots).
Diversification of Crops
Crop rotation is the practice of growing a series of different types of crops in the same area in sequential seasons to improve soil health, manage pests and diseases, and optimize yields.

Plantation farming involves the cultivation of specific cash crops, such as tea, coffee, rubber, sugarcane, oil palm, cocoa, and bananas, on large estates or plantations. These crops are grown primarily for export or commercial purposes.
Large-Scale Operations

Plantation farms are characterized by their extensive land holdings and mechanized farming practices. They often cover hundreds or thousands of hectares and employ large numbers of laborers, both permanent and seasonal.
Monoculture

Plantation farming usually involves the cultivation of a single crop species or a limited number of closely related crops on a large scale. Monoculture allows for efficient management, specialization, and optimization of production processes but may also increase susceptibility to pests, diseases, and market fluctuations.
Climate and Location

Plantation crops are typically grown in regions with specific climatic conditions and soil types that are conducive to their cultivation. For example, tea and coffee are often grown in high-altitude regions with cool temperatures, while crops like sugarcane and oil palm thrive in tropical climates.
Labor Intensive

Plantation farming historically relied heavily on manual labor, especially during planting, harvesting, and processing seasons. While mechanization has become more common in modern plantation agriculture, labor-intensive practices are still prevalent in many regions, particularly for tasks like harvesting and field maintenance.
Economic Importance

Plantation crops play a significant role in the economies of many countries, particularly in the Global South. They contribute to export earnings, employment generation, rural development, and foreign exchange revenue.
Social Considerations

Plantation farming has often been associated with social issues such as labor exploitation, land tenure conflicts, displacement of indigenous communities, and unequal distribution of benefits. Responsible plantation management involves addressing these social concerns through fair labor practices, community engagement, and sustainable land use planning.
Global Trade

Plantation crops are major commodities in global trade, with products like coffee, tea, and palm oil being traded on international markets. Plantation farming is influenced by global market dynamics, including commodity prices, trade policies, consumer preferences, and certification standards related to sustainability and ethical sourcing.
Technological Advances

Advances in agricultural technology, including mechanization, precision farming techniques, and biotechnology, have the potential to improve productivity, efficiency, and sustainability in plantation farming. However, the adoption of these technologies must be balanced with environmental and social considerations.
Watermelon
Tomato
Description

watermelon, (Citrullus lanatus), succulent fruit and vinelike plant of the gourd family (Cucurbitaceae), native to tropical Africa and cultivated around the world. The fruit contains vitamin A and some vitamin C and is usually eaten raw. The rind is sometimes preserved as a pickle.
Types and Varieties
Icebox Watermelons: These are small and perfect for individual servings
Picnic Watermelons: Larger than icebox watermelons, they’re great for sharing at picnics and gatherings.
Seedless Watermelons: As the name suggests, these varieties have few or no seeds.
Yellow-Orange Fleshed Watermelons: These have a different color of flesh, which can be yellow or orange.
Climatic Requirements
A fruit and a vegetable, belonging to the same family as cucumbers, pumpkins and squash.
Best Climate for Watermelon Watermelon plants love the heat, and need a long and warm growing season of at least 70 to 85 days, depending on the variety, to produce sweet fruit.
Best Soil for Watermelon Watermelon grows best in fertile, well-draining, sandy loam soils.
Plant Spacing for Watermelon Watermelon plants need lots of space to grow and spread out.
Watermelons can flourish in both humid and semi-arid environments. However, in humid areas, they may be more prone to fungal foliage diseases.
Common diseases of watermelon
Anthracnose
Fusarium wilt
Downy mildew
Powdery mildew
Gummy stem blight
Root-knot nematode
Virus diseases
Cercospora leaf spot
Pesticides

According to the Environmental Working Group’s Shopper’s Guide to Pesticides in Produce, watermelon clocks in at number 32 on the list, meaning that its pesticide load can be relatively high. However, this high pesticide residue is unlikely to permeate into the edible parts of the fruit, unless you plan on using the rind to make pickles.
Fertilizer for Watermelon
Well-balanced compost and/or rich, homemade compost.
Small quantities of blood meal, bone meal, and greensand when planting.
Seaweed extract; it improves the growth, production, and quality of Watermelon.
Nitrogen-based fertilizer at the onset.
Ample potassium and phosphorus for optimal melon production.
Phosphorus and potassium-based fertilizer once the plant begins flowering.
List Application
Juice: Watermelon juice is a popular beverage, especially during hot summer months, due to its hydrating properties and delicious flavor
Frozen Treats: Watermelon is used to make frozen desserts such as popsicles, sorbets, and granitas, offering a refreshing and healthy alternative to traditional ice creams.
Cocktails and Mocktails: Watermelon is used in various alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages, including cocktails, mocktails, and fruit punches, adding a tropical and summery flavor.
Facial Masks: Watermelon extract is used in skincare products such as facial masks, moisturizers, and serums due to its hydrating and soothing properties.
Hydration: Due to its high water content, watermelon is considered hydrating and can be beneficial for maintaining proper hydration levels.
Common Diseases
Strawberri
The tomato is the fruit of the plant Solanum lycopersicum, which has culinary importance, and is a vegetable.
Globe: round, medium-sized, red or yellow, good for slicing and salads
Beefsteak: large, irregular-shaped, red or pink, juicy and meaty, good for sandwiches and burgers.
Cherry: small, round, red or yellow, sweet and tangy, good for snacking and salads
Plum: oval, medium-sized, red or yellow, firm and fleshy, good for sauces and canning
Oxheart: heart-shaped, large, red or pink, dense and flavorful, good for stuffing and slicing
Tomato plants require temperature between 10˚C and 34˚C
Tomato plants require temperature between 10˚C and 34˚C
Tomato plants will grow well in well-drained sites that receive full sun for most of the day
The soil pH should be slightly acidic (6.2 to 6.8)
Crown and root rot, caused by fungal or bacterial infection of the roots and stems.
Fusarium wilt, caused by a soil-borne fungus that blocks the water transport in the plant.
Late blight, caused by a fungus that creates gray, moldy patches on the leaves and fruits.
Bacterial spot, caused by a bacterium that creates small, water-soaked lesions on the leaves and fruits.
Septoria leaf spot, caused by a fungus that creates small, circular patches with a grayish-white center and dark edges on the leaves.
Early blight, caused by a fungus that creates brown spots on the leaves and stems.

Many pesticides used on tomatoes are of concern due to biological, regulatory and social issues. In the US, and California in particular, the Food Quality Protection, Clean Water, Toxic Air Contaminants, and Safe Drinking Water and Toxic Enforcement Acts represent regulations potentially affecting pesticides registered on processing tomatoes.
Fertilize Tomatoes
At planting time fertilizers with a higher percentage of nitrogen, such as a 20-10-10 can be applied to support healthy foliage and growth.
Prior to transplanting is a good time to add aged manure or compost to your tomato plant\'s intended spot.
Around two weeks before flowering is a good time to use a fertilizer with a higher P value, such as a 5-15-5
Roma Tomatoes: Also known as paste tomatoes, Romas are elongated and have fewer seeds. They are commonly used for making sauces, pastes, and canning.
Beefsteak Tomatoes: These hefty tomatoes have a meaty texture and are larger in size.
Standard Globe Tomatoes: Also known as salad tomatoes, these classic tomatoes are about 2 to 3 inches wide. They have a tart, acidic taste and are great for slicing and eating raw
Cherry Tomatoes: These sweet, bite-sized tomatoes are perfect for snacking, adding to salads, or roasting. Their vibrant color and juicy flavor make them a delightful addition to any dish
strawberry, (genus Fragaria), genus of more than 20 species of flowering plants in the rose family (Rosaceae) and their edible fruit.

There are three types of strawberries: June-bearing, everbearing, and day-neutral. Sometimes everbearing and day-neutral types are grouped together as they have many similarities. Gardeners commonly grow both a June-bearing and a day-neutral variety to get fresh berries from June through until frost.
Temperate Climate: Strawberries grow best in temperate climates. They are well-suited to areas with distinct seasons, including cold winters and warm summers.
Short Day Plant: Strawberries are considered short day plants. This means they require exposure to approximately 10 days of less than 8 hours of sunshine to initiate flowering.
Winter Dormancy: During winter, strawberry plants remain dormant and do not actively grow. Exposure to low temperatures during this period helps break their dormancy.
Spring Growth: As days become longer and temperatures rise in spring, the plants resume growth and start flowering.
Compost-Rich, Loamy Soil: Plant strawberries in compost-rich, loamy soil with excellent drainage.
Optimal Range: Strawberries require a temperature range of 60-80°F (15-26°C) for optimal growth.
Leaf scorch
Leaf spot
Leaf blight
Grey mould
Botrytis (Gray Mold)
Strawberries should be thoroughly cleaned to remove pesticides and bacteria.
Wait to clean strawberries until you plan to eat them to help keep their structure.
Strawberries can be washed in a vinegar or saltwater solution.
Use a balanced fertilizer such as 10-10-10 or 20-20-20, or a low-phosphorus fertilizer, to avoid burning the plants.
Add fertilizer to the soil before planting, and then again one month after planting.
For potted plants, use a combination of potting mix, compost, and granular fertilizer.
Ornamental Tree: The colorful bark and twisted branches make it a lovely decorative tree.
Edible Fruits: While not true strawberries, the fruit is edible and has a unique flavor.
Environmental Impact: Positive due to its evergreen nature and aesthetic appeal.
Lime
Lime is also an inorganic material composed primarily of calcium oxides and hydroxides
The flavor of a lime is stronger and more tart than a lemon, but it can typically be substituted for a lemon2
It is used in food dishes to provide a tart taste as an ingredient

Lime is not a fertilizer but can be used in combination with fertilizers. It improves crop yield and the root system of plants and grass where soils are acidic by making the soil more basic, allowing the plants to absorb more nutrients.

Lime trees can be fertilized with either a commercial chemical fertilizer specially formulated for citrus trees or if you are concerned about runoff, they can be fed with garden compost or animal manure.

The best fertilizer for a lime tree is one with an NPK (nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium) ratio of 2:1:1, such as 6-3-3. For best results, fertilizers should also be organic, slow-release, and come from a reputable brand.
Benefits: Tricholime ensures optimal plant growth, nutrient uptake, and the growth of useful microbes in soil.
Scientists at the ICAR-Indian Institute of Spices Research (ICAR-IISR) have developed an innovative product called Tricholime.
Hydrated lime, also known as calcium hydroxide, has been used as a basic pesticide for many years.
Sooty Mold It is caused due to pest infestations, especially because of the citrus whitefly
Scab Disease It is caused by the fungus Elsinoë fawcettii, and it usually affects leaves and fruits. The leaf areas are discolored, and raised from the surrounding surfaces
If you’re in a region prone to strong winds or hurricanes, consider planting windbreaks around your lime orchard.
While limes prefer a humid climate, they can tolerate
These zesty green gems crave plenty of sunlight.
Limes thrive in semi-tropical and warm-temperate regions.
Climatic Requirements Lemons thrive in subtropical and tropical climates with temperatures from 21°C to 37°C.
Tahiti limes are often confused with Bearss limes due to their similar appearance.
Bearss limes, also known as Persian limes, are larger than Key limes.
Apart from Key limes, there are other types of Mexican limes with similar characteristics.
These small, round limes have a strong acidic flavor and aroma
Lime is a citrus fruit that is typically round, green in color, 3–6 centimetres (1.2–2.4 in) in diameter, and contains acidic juice vesicles
Banana
Fiber: Banana trees can be used to make rope and fabric.
Animal Feed: Banana trees can also be used as animal feed. The leaves and stems can feed cattle, goats, and sheep.
Fruit: Bananas are the most popular use for banana trees. They can be baked with, eaten raw, or cooked

The best fertilizers for banana plants include organic compost, balanced NPK, banana peel fertilizer, vermicompost, potassium-rich fertilizers, liquid seaweed fertilizer, slow-release fertilizers, and organic banana special fertilizer.
Azoxystrobin: A fungicide, used for a variety of produce farming.
Thiabendazole: A fungicide and parasiticide.
Chlorpyrifos: An insecticide, acaricide and miticide, used on many crops throughout the world.

Trees are susceptible to a variety of diseases that can damage or even kill them. The most common types of tree diseases are fungal diseases, bacterial diseases, and virus-caused diseases. Fungal diseases are the most common, and can be caused by fungi that attack the roots, leaves, branches, or bark.
Sunlight: Mango trees require full sunlight for optimal growth and fruit production.
Soil: Well-drained, deep, and fertile soil is essential for healthy mango trees. Sandy loam or loamy soil with a pH range of 5.5 to 7.5 is ideal.
Relative Humidity: Mango trees prefer a relative humidity of 70% to 90% during the growing season.
Rainfall: An annual rainfall range of 890-1,015 mm is considered ideal for mango cultivation. However, mangoes can be grown in regions with both heavy (2,540 mm) or scanty (254 mm) rainfall
Temperature: Higher temperatures during fruit development and maturity yield better-quality fruits.
Gros Michel: Before the rise of Cavendish bananas, Gros Michel was the predominant variety. However, it faced challenges due to Panama disease.
Cavendish Bananas: The most popular type, making up 95% of all bananas eaten in the USA. They’re widely available and sold everywhere.
Bluggoe Banana: These large, starchy bananas are native to Ecuador. Although more expensive than the common Cavendish variety, Bluggoe bananas are often used for cooking.
Blue Java Banana: With a blue peel and white flesh, Blue Java bananas are grown in Southeast Asia and Hawaii.
Barangan Banana: Grown primarily in Malaysia, these small and sweet bananas are both popular locally and exported. Unfortunately, they’re challenging to find for sale in the United States.
Apple Banana: Native to Southeast Asia, these bananas have a hint of apple flavor
A banana is an elongated, edible fruit – botanically a berry – produced by several kinds of large herbaceous flowering plants in the genus Musa
Mangoes are popular due to their wide adaptability, high nutritive value, variety, delicious taste, and excellent flavor.
India ranks first among the world’s mango-producing countries, accounting for approximately 50% of global mango production.
Use fertilizers with a combination of phosphorus, potassium, and nitrogen, along with manganese, zinc, and iron.
Use a complete fertilizer containing 6 to 10 percent nitrogen, 6 to 10 percent phosphorus, and 4 to 6 percent magnesium for young mango trees.
Use a balanced fertilizer mix containing 6-10% potassium, phosphorus, and nitrogen.
Majority of insecticides used belong to WHO category II
Most farmers use conventional insecticides to control insect pests in mango
Thiabendazole was the most common pesticide in contaminated mangoes
78% of mango samples did not have any measurable pesticide residues
Mango scab: A fungus that causes black spots on new fruit.
Bacterial black spot: A disease that attacks mango leaves, twigs and fruit.
Powdery mildew: A fungal disease that affects the flowers and causes young fruits to dehydrate and fall.
Anthracnose: A fungal disease that causes black spots on leaves and fruit.
Mangoes can be grown from sea level up to 1,400 meters altitude.
Mango trees prefer well-drained soils with a pH range of 5.5 to 7.5.
An annual rainfall range of 890 mm to 1,015 mm is considered ideal for growing mangoes.
The ideal temperature range for mango growth during the growing season is 24°C to 27°C
It can be grown under both tropical and sub-tropical climate from sea level to 1400 m altitude, provided there is no high humidity, rain or frost during the flowering period.

The Mango Tree, scientifically known as Mangifera indica, is a tropical fruit tree that belongs to the Anacardiaceae family
Onion
onion, (Allium cepa), herbaceous biennial plant in the amaryllis family (Amaryllidaceae) grown for its edible bulb.
The Hidden Wiki: Imagine Wikipedia, but specifically for the dark web. It hosts a comprehensive directory of onion links, allowing you to explore various corners of this hidden part of the internet
DuckDuckGo: The largest search engine on the dark web that prioritizes privacy by not using trackers or collecting personal data1. It’s a great alternative to mainstream search engines.

To fertilize onions, you can use balanced granular fertilizers with ratios such as 10-10-10 or 12-12-121. Nitrogen-rich fertilizers such as ammonium sulfate, calcium nitrate, or feather meal are also suitable. Other fertilizers that can be used for onions include compost, fish emulsion, bone meal, blood meal, worm castings, ammonium nitrate, superphosphate, potassium sulfate, calcium nitrate, and urea. During the first few weeks of onion’s development, apply a 10-20-10 fertilizer to the bed where you’ll plant the onions.

Onions and garlic can be used as a pesticide to keep bugs away from plants123. The sulfur compounds in the onion and garlic produce an odor that pests do not like1. Garlic and onions can be mixed with water in a spray bottle and then applied to plants or they can be used alone. You can make a basic garlic spray to control aphids, slugs, and other insects, or you can make an onion, chili, and garlic spray that will help keep away ladybugs, caterpillars, deer, and other insects and animals as well.
The six most common diseases affecting onion farms are damping off, bacterial soft rot, Stemphylium leaf blight, purple blotch, fusarium basal rot, and alternaria leaf blight.
Onions can be cultivated in various soil types.For maximum yield, loamy soil is most suitable.
They flourish when exposed to 10 to 12 hours of sunlight while extracting tubers.
Onions thrive in cool climates. They are primarily winter crops.

Climatic Requirements Onion is very sensitive to sunlight and temperature. It is primarily a winter crop. Usually it requires 10 to 15 ° C for good growth and 20 to 30 ° C for growth of tubers, and 30 to 35 ° C temperature and 10 to 12 hours of sunlight while extracting tubers.

Maui Onion

Bermuda Onion
Small, pear-shaped onions with a sweet and delicate flavor.
Named after the Scottish island of Ailsa Craig, these onions are renowned for their large size and mild flavor.
